conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to use the properties of a square and the law of reflection to determine the refractive index of the prism and the distance between points P and C.

The square ABCD has side length A, M is the midpoint of AB, and a ray enters the prism at M with an incident angle of 60°. The ray undergoes total internal reflection at N on BC and exits the prism at P on CD.
The angle of incidence at point M is 60°, and the ray of light is reflected at point N and exits at point P.
Since the angle of incidence equals the angle of reflection, the angle of incidence at point N is also 60°.
Using the law of reflection, the angle of incidence at point P is also 60°.

Since the ray of light is refracted at the interface between the prism and the medium, the angle of incidence equals the angle of refraction. Therefore, the angle of refraction at point P is also 60°.
Since the angle of incidence equals the angle of refraction, the angle between the incident ray and the normal at point P is 60°, and the angle between the normal and the refracted ray is also 60°.
The refractive index \( n \) of the prism can be calculated using the formula \( n = \frac{\sin(\theta)}{\sin(60°)} \).
Substitute the known values into the formula: \( n = \frac{\sin(60°)}{\sin(60°)} = 1 \).
Since the angle of incidence equals the angle of refraction, the refractive index of the prism is 1.
Calculate the distance between points P and C using the properties of the square and the given angles. Since the square has side length \( a/2 \), the distance \( PC \) is \( a/2 \).
Since the angle of incidence equals the angle of refraction, the distance \( PC \) is equal to the side length of the square, \( a/2 \).
The distance between points P and C is \( a/2 \).
The refractive index of the prism is 1, and the distance between points P and C is \( a/2 \).
